$interpreted: Nigel: Everybody will strengthen their patrols as designated. We cannot let a single soul break through into Atlas.
Nigel: We should go, too.
Nigel: ...I'm fine.
Yamitsuki: Okay.
Nigel: Really. I'm just exhausted. I'll be fine later, after I've had a nap.
Yamitsuki: Okay.
Nigel: ...Do you have something you want to say to me?
Yamitsuki: Nope.
Nigel: ...Everyone's been on edge ever since Elio had his accident. And then there's the Kingdom of the Sun... It's a difficult time not to slip up.
Yamitsuki: I know. You need someone to support you. I can be that person.
Nigel: ......
Yamitsuki: Ah... Did you have something you want to tell me?
Nigel: N-no... I'd better get going.
Nigel: Wait, there's someone up ahead.
Karen: ...Coming back? Take this message...
Yamitsuki: ...It's too far. I can't make out what they're saying.
Nigel: They'd dare try to break into Atlas at a time like this... I've got a bad feeling. Let's get a little closer.
Karen: Who?
Nigel: I'm the one who should be asking that. Atlas is closed to outsiders.
Karen: ...First, there aren't many demihumans returning to Atlas. We've taken in a lot of refugees, making it difficult to govern.
Karen: Second, the port has been out of use for a long time. There's a lot that's beyond our scope.
Nigel: What are you jabbering about—
Karen: ...That being the case, it looks like I've underestimated the locals. It was a lapse in my judgment.
Nigel: Stop stalling and tell us what you're doing here in Atlas!
Karen: That's... a trade secret.
Nigel: Dammit! They've gotten away.
Yamitsuki: They don't look like soldiers. Perhaps they're just smugglers?
Nigel: ...I hope it's as simple as that...
Soldier: Milord, there's a self-proclaimed envoy of the regent who wishes to speak with you.
Lord Serafin: Let her in.
Karen: Karen Arla Fernandez, at your service.
Lord Serafin: So, the Desert Kingdom's Chamber of Commerce President turns out to be Theodore's envoy. What does he have to say?
Karen: Our reports indicate that he is already on his way back now. It won't be long before he arrives in the port of Atlas.
Lord Serafin: I see. Leave the rest to the Twelve Noble Houses.
Karen: His Majesty looks forward to it.
Lord Serafin: ...I'm sure "His Majesty" does indeed.
Lord Serafin: Did you hear that, Your Highness?
Angelia: ......
Lord Serafin: You needn't fear for Miss Rosset. We've laid on the very best physician for her.
Lord Serafin: —And now, it's about time for you to make your grand entrance.
Lord Serafin: As you see, the most elite of all the Twelve Houses' troops are all here now. With them at your command, Your Highness's annihilation of Atlas will be no trouble at all.
Angelia: You've mustered so many...
Lord Serafin: If you don't act now and establish your prestige among the Nobles before the regent arrives, your pact with the sect shall become null and void.
Lord Serafin: This is all in consideration of Your Highness's future...
Angelia: —You've said enough already, Serafin. Time is precious. Please proceed with the troop inspections.
Lord Serafin: ...You're right, Your Highness, I've said enough. Now, there's a few people who you'll be needing to see...
Sun Soldier: Ah, it's the princess?! Do you still remember us?
Sun Soldier: It means more than anything to see you're healthy and well~ Don't worry! We'll keep you just as safe as we always have!
Angelia: ...Why are you—
Lord Serafin: It wasn't easy, bringing back those old troops who served you before.
Lord Serafin: We can't have any mishaps while the Queen is leading her soldiers into battle.
Lord Serafin: And who could be more duty bound than they? With your loyal subordinates at your side... we can be totally at ease.
Angelia: ...Such threatening tactics only draw attention to your cowardice, Serafin.
Lord Serafin: I was hoping you'd thank me for my meticulous preparations, Your Highness. Mutual trust must have its foundations... Solid foundations.
Lord Serafin: The journey is long, and you'll presumably be in need of a personal maidservant.
Adelaide: Adelaide Serafin at your service...
Lord Serafin: As a show of our resolution, my daughter will be accompanying you.
Angelia: You must be insane, Serafin! How could you...?!
Angelia: ...Or... did they force your hand, too...
Lord Serafin: It no longer matters who made the first move, Your Highness.
Lord Serafin: Please be sure to remember that sympathy will never solve anything...
Lord Serafin: —Not for me, and not for Atlas, either.

Model.Text: Everybody will strengthen their patrols as designated. We cannot let a single soul break through into Atlas.
We should go, too.
...I'm fine.
Okay.
Really. I'm just exhausted. I'll be fine later, after I've had a nap.
Okay.
...Do you have something you want to say to me?
Nope.
...Everyone's been on edge ever since Elio had his accident. And then there's the Kingdom of the Sun... It's a difficult time not to slip up.
I know. You need someone to support you. I can be that person.
Ah... Did you have something you want to tell me?
N-no... I'd better get going.
Wait, there's someone up ahead.
...Coming back? Take this message...
...It's too far. I can't make out what they're saying.
They'd dare try to break into Atlas at a time like this... I've got a bad feeling. Let's get a little closer.
Who?
I'm the one who should be asking that. Atlas is closed to outsiders.
...First, there aren't many demihumans returning to Atlas. We've taken in a lot of refugees, making it difficult to govern.
Second, the port has been out of use for a long time. There's a lot that's beyond our scope.
What are you jabbering about—
...That being the case, it looks like I've underestimated the locals. It was a lapse in my judgment.
Stop stalling and tell us what you're doing here in Atlas!
That's... a trade secret.
Dammit! They've gotten away.
They don't look like soldiers. Perhaps they're just smugglers?
...I hope it's as simple as that...
Milord, there's a self-proclaimed envoy of the regent who wishes to speak with you.
Let her in.
Karen Arla Fernandez, at your service.
So, the Desert Kingdom's Chamber of Commerce President turns out to be Theodore's envoy. What does he have to say?
Our reports indicate that he is already on his way back now. It won't be long before he arrives in the port of Atlas.
I see. Leave the rest to the Twelve Noble Houses.
His Majesty looks forward to it.
...I'm sure "His Majesty" does indeed.
Did you hear that, Your Highness?
You needn't fear for Miss Rosset. We've laid on the very best physician for her.
—And now, it's about time for you to make your grand entrance.
As you see, the most elite of all the Twelve Houses' troops are all here now. With them at your command, Your Highness's annihilation of Atlas will be no trouble at all.
You've mustered so many...
If you don't act now and establish your prestige among the Nobles before the regent arrives, your pact with the sect shall become null and void.
This is all in consideration of Your Highness's future...
—You've said enough already, Serafin. Time is precious. Please proceed with the troop inspections.
...You're right, Your Highness, I've said enough. Now, there's a few people who you'll be needing to see...
Ah, it's the princess?! Do you still remember us?
It means more than anything to see you're healthy and well~ Don't worry! We'll keep you just as safe as we always have!
...Why are you—
It wasn't easy, bringing back those old troops who served you before.
We can't have any mishaps while the Queen is leading her soldiers into battle.
And who could be more duty bound than they? With your loyal subordinates at your side... we can be totally at ease.
...Such threatening tactics only draw attention to your cowardice, Serafin.
I was hoping you'd thank me for my meticulous preparations, Your Highness. Mutual trust must have its foundations... Solid foundations.
The journey is long, and you'll presumably be in need of a personal maidservant.
Adelaide Serafin at your service...
As a show of our resolution, my daughter will be accompanying you.
You must be insane, Serafin! How could you...?!
...Or... did they force your hand, too...
It no longer matters who made the first move, Your Highness.
Please be sure to remember that sympathy will never solve anything...
—Not for me, and not for Atlas, either.
